headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Colgate-Palmolive Company Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded and is being simulcast live at www.colgatepalmolive.com.Today's conference call will include for
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Colgate-Palmolive Company Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded and is being simulcast live at www.colgatepalmolive.com.
Today's conference call will include forward-looking statements. These statements are made on the basis of our views and assumptions as of this time and are not guarantees of future performance.
Actual events or results may differ materially from these statements. So for information about certain factors that could cause such differences, investors should consult our most recent annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and available on our website, including the information set forth under the captions Risk Factors and Cautionary Statement on forward-looking statements.
This conference call will also include a discussion of non-GAAP financial measures, which differ from our results prepared in accordance with GAAP. We will discuss organic sales growth, which is net sales growth, excluding foreign exchange, acquisitions and divestitures.
We will also discuss gross profit, gross profit margin, SG&A, SG&A as a percent of net sales, operating profit, operating profit margin, net income and earnings per share on a diluted basis, excluding the impact of the items described in the press release.
A full reconciliation with the corresponding GAAP measures is included in the press release and is posted in the For Investors section of our website at www.colgatepalmolive.com.
Just a reminder, there may be a slight delay before the question-and-answer session begins due to the Web simulcast.
Now for opening remarks, I'd like to turn the call over to the Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Bina Thompson. Please go ahead, Bina.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cathy, and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call.With me this morning are Ian Cook, Chairman, President and CEO; Dennis Hickey, CFO; Victoria Dolan, Corporate Controller; and Elaine Paik, Tre
componenttext:
Thanks, Cathy, and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call.
With me this morning are Ian Cook, Chairman, President and CEO; Dennis Hickey, CFO; Victoria Dolan, Corporate Controller; and Elaine Paik, Treasurer.
We're pleased to exit 2014 with organic sales up 6% as compared to the fourth quarter of 2013, which was the strongest quarter of last year. Our market shares are strong around the world as you will hear in a moment. As always, innovation has been critical to our success and we're excited about our pipeline looking forward to 2015 and beyond. 
In many markets, macroeconomic challenges persist. And, of course, foreign exchange has been and will continue to be a considerable headwind as translational low is projected to impact EPS in 2015 over 10% at current foreign exchange rates. That makes us even more pleased to be able to deliver content organic sales growth and positive results on the bottom line. 
While our gross margin was down in the quarter due to very significant transaction costs, we believe that we'll see an improving trend as we move through 2015 with the more benign or material cost environment and pricing taken to offset the impact of rising transaction costs related to foreign exchange. Our funding-the-growth program is robust as ever and our Global Growth and Efficiency Program is on track. Savings generated in 2014 related to the Global Growth and Efficiency Program were over $100 million after tax and above the top end of our projected range. Overhead expenses are down in the quarter due to tight controls in all divisions and savings from our Global Growth and Efficiency Program. Our total commercial spending also increased in support of both existing and new products. 
We think we're well poised to meet the challenges we face as we enter 2015. We believe our strong balance sheet and a solid cash generation should keep us in good stead. 
So turning to North America. We're very pleased with our progress here. Innovation is contributing to organic sales growth and we had more plans for this year. In the fourth quarter, in the U.S., our market share increased year-to-date in toothpaste and manual toothbrushes and was even with the prior year in mouthwash. Results were strong across our portfolio in toothpaste. Our Colgate Total toothpaste share remains over 10%, supported by fresh, the relaunch of Colgate Total Advanced Whitening and the boost provided by our companion, Colgate Total Lasting White mouthwash. The Colgate Optic White franchises also doing well as the superpremium line is driving incrementality with its year-to-date toothpaste share up from 5.3% to 5.6%. And, as you know, we also launched Colgate enamel health toothpaste and toothbrushes in the second half of 2014. It's off to a strong start and our overall toothpaste share is up 1.4% in the 3 months after its launch as compared to the 3 months prior. 
In the mouthwash category, our year-to-date share is up more than a full point while our 2 major competitors' full year shares declined, with excellent results from Colgate Total Lasting White mouthwash. Our fabric conditioner business continues to perform well. Both for the full year and the quarter, our market share is up over a full point to a new record, close to 20% of the overall market and as you know, these products are primarily sold and Hispanic markets. And as you would expect, we have more innovation slated for 2015 with a full plan for the first quarter. In toothpaste, we're launching Colgate Optic White Express White toothpaste. This innovation provides whiter teeth in just 3 days simply by brushing with best results after 4 weeks of brushing as directed. It's Colgate's fastest whitening toothpaste and is enamel safe for daily use. In the mouthwash category, we're launching Colgate Total Gum Health mouthwash. It provides advanced gum protection for 45% stronger, healthier gums versus a none antibacterial mouthwash. Fast between teeth and along the gum line and it kills 99% of terms on contact with 12-hour protection against bacteria that cause gingivitis. In the toothbrush category, we're launching Colgate sensitive toothbrush plus sensitivity. Using the same innovative pen application technology that's been so successful in the whitening segment. This pen utilizes our patented Pro-Argin Technology to deliver sensitivity relief 24/7 with continued use and goes right to the source of the pain. To begin the momentum in the dish liquid category, we're launching a premium price Palmolive multiservice, which is specially formulated to kill bacteria on dishes and hard, non-core kitchen surfaces. And on the value side, we're launching Ajax all-in-one dish liquid, which has a new formula with 10% more cleaning ingredients than before. And to further our success in the fabric conditioner category, we're launching Suavitel fragrance pro with a proprietary sense system, which provides 5x longer lasting fragrance compared with using detergent alone, as well as Suavitel Fast Dry dryer sheet, which helped loads dry 30% faster than using detergent alone. 
Turning then to Europe/South Pacific. We enjoyed another quarter of organic sales growth in this region with a slight acceleration in volume from the third quarter. Our commercial hub and activities, part of our Global Growth and Efficiency Program, are now complete and were implemented with very little disruption. In fact in the quarter, virtually all new hubs delivered positive organic sales growth. Innovation is critical in this part of the world and it continues to contribute to market share growth in a number of our categories. Our market shares across Europe are up year-to-date in toothpaste, manual toothbrush, battery toothbrush, mouthwash, liquid hand soaps and dish liquids. Of note, all categories of our aesthetic business has grown market share year-to-date; shower gel, liquid hand soap and underarm protection. Our launch of Colgate Maximum Cavity Protection plus Sugar Acid Neutralizers is now complete across the region with excellent share results in a number of markets. 1 of our first launch markets, Denmark, posted a 4.1% share in the most recent period and 2 larger more recent market launch markets, the U.K. and France, have already achieved 1.5% and 2% shares, respectively in the most recent periods. 
Building on this success in 2015, we will continue full marketing support for the toothpaste along with the further rollout of a companion toothbrush and mouthwash. As I just mentioned, our Sanex business is performing well and we have exciting new product activity to support further growth. Launching in the first quarter is Sanex Advance, Sanex's first bodycare regimen developed with leading dermatologists. Available in 3 different formulations, the regimen will include a body lotion and hand cream to complement the body wash and deodorant. This is Sanex's first entry into the hand and body lotion category. The Sanex Advanced Dermal Repair Bundle for dry skin with minor damage that we contains active restore complex and alantoin to restore pH balance in moisturization. The Sanex advanced derm bundle for extra try atopic skin contains skin-identical lipids and to help restore the skin's protective barrier, itchiness and control hypersensitivity, helping the skin to keep functioning normally. 
The Sanex Advanced Hydrate 24H bundle for very dry, dehydrated skin uses active technology in the shower gel and lotion, which has a ceramide and glycerine to maintain the skin's protective barrier by locking in the moisture. And in addition, we'll be launching Sanex in Poland, a new geography, which will provide incremental new business for us. 
Turning then to Latin America. Business business across this region is solid. Organic sales growth accelerated from the prior 2 quarters in 2014 and while volume increased a modest 1% versus the year ago period, this was on top of the very strong increase of 10% in the fourth quarter of 2013. Toothpaste shares are strong across the region. In Mexico, our most recent share is 80.8%, up 80 basis points from the year-ago period. Colgate Maximum Cavity Protection has achieved 2% share in the most recent period. In Brazil in December, our toothpaste share reached 72.1% for the month, the highest share in the past 18 years. This is in spite of a lot of competitive activity. Our manual toothbrush business is performing well. In Mexico, we achieved a record share of 45% in the latest reading while for the first time our major competitor dropped below the 40% share. Growth was across all retail environments, self-service stores, pharmacies and the indirect trade. We reached a record year-to-date share in Brazil as well with good growth in the superpremium segment with a 32.4% share of the market, the #1 position. In bar soaps, we strengthen our leadership position across the region, up 0.5 point on a year-to-date basis to 29.7% with the most recent read at 29.9%. 
Innovation in both the Palmolive and Protex equities has contributed to this success. And in the home care category, our year-to-date regional market shares have increased in fabric conditioners of 50 basis points to 51.6% and in liquid cleaners, up 70 basis points to 36.3%. And we have more exciting new products planned for 2015 across all our categories. In the first quarter, specifically, we're excited about a new subcategory in their Protex body cleansing category. Feminine intimate wash. Protex is a branded that's recognized as an experts in skin protection and this positioning should transfer readily into the intimate care sub category. It will be launched for the full integrated marketing campaign, including a product website and endorsement through a well-known journalist. Primary replacement in-store will be on the intimate shelves with secondary replacement on the soap shelf to attract attention from from loyal Protex users. 
Turning then to Asia. We're pleased with the acceleration of organic sales growth in this region as we indicated would happened last quarter. And as referenced in the press release, we saw good toothpaste market share gains in a number of countries. In India, our market share increased to 54.4%, up 30 basis points on a year-to-date basis. Colgate Active Salt toothpaste, especially for this market were antibacterial efficacy increased 70 basis points to over a 5% share. In Malaysia, our year-to-date share's up 30 basis points to just over 73%. Anti-cavity segment now comprises almost 27% of the market and Colgate Maximum Cavity Protection toothpaste launched last February has a 3.2% share year-to-date with the most recent lead of 4%. In manual toothbrushes, our regional share increased 20 basis points year-to-date to 30.2%, with 8 out of 10 countries reporting stable to positive growth. In India, our share reached a record 43.2%, up 120 basis points on a year-to-date basis. 
Innovation under the Colgate Slim Soft equity has been particularly successful. And our regional mouthwash share increased 120 basis points year-to-date to 23.1%, with the most recent period at 24.6%. 
Looking forward, in toothpaste, we will be relaunching both our base sensitivity line, as well as the Colgate Sensitive Pro release line. In addition we will be adding Colgate Sensitive Pro release Repair and Prevent. This new product has the unique Coliseum and amino acid complex, which it refers their root cause of sensitivity, preventing the pain from returning. 
In India, we will be launching Colgate Active Salt with. The tree in India is known for its antibacterial properties. In certain markets, we will also introduce a line of kid's toothpaste for children aged 2 to 5, a segment currently somewhat underdeveloped that would present a great incremental opportunity. New in the mouthwash category will be Colgate Plax Bamboo Charcoal and, as you know, charcoal is also widely viewed as an ingredient to fight bacteria. 
Turning then to Africa/Eurasia. This region continues to deliver strong organic sales growth despite some macroeconomic challenges in countries such as Russia. Original toothpaste share is up 10 basis points to 32.4% year-to-date and despite difficulties in Russia and the Ukraine, our year-to-date share is up 10 basis points to 32.9% in Russia and up 170 basis points in the Ukraine to 28.2%. We've also seen good share increases across sub-Saharan Africa and the North Africa. In manual toothbrushes, Colgate 360° and Colgate Slim Soft have helped increase our share in Turkey, up 30 basis points year-to-date to 28.7%. In South Africa, we are up 380 basis points year-to-date to over 38% of the market. And across the region, our mouthwash shares are up 30 basis points year-to-date, approaching 20%. Colgate is the #2 mouthwash brand in Africa/Eurasia. You may recall we told you about the new product in Russia, Colgate Altai Herbs mouthwash. That has contributed to a 210 basis point increase in our Russian mouthwash share to 27.5% year-to-date. We also have a good market-leading shower gel business in this region. Our year-to-date share is up 120 basis points to almost 22%. Russia, Turkey and South Africa have all reached record shares. We've told you on previous calls about our Palmolive Gourmet Spa line with enticing coffee, chocolate, vanilla and peach fragrances. That innovation has been 1 of the drivers of the excellent share performance. And innovation this quarter continues. This for the relaunch of our Colgate Total toothpaste portfolio, we have initiated a new integrated marketing campaign around the idea of the incredible mouth. The idea is that Colgate knows that your mouth is incredible, unique, which is why Colgate developed Colgate Total to protect 100% of your mouth, not only your teeth. 
To continue the momentum in our shower gel business, we're launching Palmolive Taiga Freshness for Men. You may recall we've had great success for the Colgate herbs products toothpaste, mouthwash and body cleansing. Altai is a region in Russia known for its herbs, which are believed to have curative properties. Similarly, Taiga is the Northern Forest characterized by pines, trees and marshes covering much of Northern Eurasia. This new product offers the freshness and cleanness of the legendary Taiga in your shower. Finally, Hill's. We're pleased with Hill's continued good organic sales growth of 4% in the quarter particularly when compared to a strong 7% growth in the year-ago quarter. Innovation has driven good results across our science diet, Prescription Diet and Ideal Balance portfolio. For the science diet portfolio, nutritional consultant Shaffer engagement and superstores and when you sell favorites with your the U.S. has helped drive sales. In Europe, Hill's Science Plan Perfect Weight has been supported with secondary displays in store and in-store weighing area and on-shelf dynamic screens to explain the product benefits. Here in the U.S., Hill's Ideal Balance has gained share in both the wellness and natural segments and consumption of the product in superstores was up strongly versus the year-ago period. In Europe, the product sustained excellent trade acceptance in the U.K. and Germany, 2 large set food markets we've received support with promotional activities and secondary placements. And our Prescription Diet metabolic line continues to made with success. To build on that, this quarter, we're launching Prescription Diet metabolic plus. 32 million pets obesity-related concurrent conditions. This is the first and only dual efficacy therapeutic pet nutrition food. It will be available for weight loss plus mobility for dogs and weight loss plus urinary stress for CATs. The product will be available in both a try and stew format. And also they're excited about the new global packaging redesign across the Prescription Diet range. With consumer friendly packaging and new better tasting for glass, the bundle is they bond the least they bond the least is centigrade a stronger emotional connection, strengthen our leadership and innovation credentials and the improved taste perception. That's rolling out across the U.S., Canada and some of the high-growth markets in the first quarter of 2015 and Europe in the second quarter. 
So in summary, we believe our solid results for the quarter are a good indication that we have an effective strategy and we believe that this consistent strategy has stood as well for many years. You know it well. Staying close to the customer and consumer, innovating everywhere, becoming more effective and efficient and ongoing leadership development. We believe our Executive son the ground have the tools to make the right decision to volume, supporting innovation, in story and outcome increasing market share, all this is winning on the ground. We and our competition alike our faced with choppy times, volatile currency and macroeconomic challenges in many parts of the world so we believe it's a simple consistent focus well understood by every Colgate person that makes the difference. 
And now I'd like to turn it over to Q&A.
Cathy?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Will first go to Steve Powers from UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Will first go to Steve Powers from UBS.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ian, maybe just a few little things to kick us off on if we could. First, August out of it provided the gross margin bridge for Q4 and maybe talk a little bit about how those drivers are expected to trend in 2015? And any changes in margin improvement or
componenttext: Ian, maybe just a few little things to kick us off on if we could. First, August out of it provided the gross margin bridge for Q4 and maybe talk a little bit about how those drivers are expected to trend in 2015? And any changes in margin improvement or organic growth expectations for the year versus last quarter's outlook would be great. And then maybe could you also provide a little update on volume and sales trends in China and Brazil specifically. It looks like things improved as expected in China but you were still battling through some inventory issues in Brazil. Just curious if that's a fair read and just expectations on and how you expect momentum to trend from here.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I think as Bina said at the end of her prepared remarks, I guess we live in a world these days where focus is really important but so is agility. And I don't think you saw in the fourth quarter the agility and the balance, I guess, between volume and
componenttext:
Well I think as Bina said at the end of her prepared remarks, I guess we live in a world these days where focus is really important but so is agility. And I don't think you saw in the fourth quarter the agility and the balance, I guess, between volume and price as our 6% was composed of volume growth in all divisions and pricing increases largely in the developing world. So if we take that to the gross profit roll forward, and you go back to the prior year gross profit, 59.1, we benefited from 1.4 points of pricing as you can see a step-up from the prior 3 quarters between our Funding the Growth and restructuring, we had something like 280 basis points of benefit. And then faced the headwind in terms of material prices of some 4.3 points, of which 2 points for the quarter was transaction. And then there were 20 basis points negative of some other minor changes, which gets you to the 58.8% gross margin. Interestingly, although we are where we are, if you were to go back to the October conversation we had and our expectations for the fourth quarter for gross margin to be even with prior year, if you just strip out the exchange deterioration since our October call, in fact, for this quarter, our gross margin would have been at prior year level. What we managed to do by moving quickly on pricing was to offset the dollar impact of foreign exchange but not yet the ratio impact. So that's 2014. When you go forward into 2015, I guess you've got a few things in terms of our view on gross margin. Our view on gross margin for 2015 is that we will expand it between 50 and 100 basis points on the year your now that is going to progress through the year from the first to the fourth quarter. We get a benefit in 2015, of course, from the current oil prices, which we expect to work through towards the end of the first half next year. And, of course, commodity materials, which our forecast would say are more or less flat year-on-year. 
And these are benefits we haven't seen in prior years. We will continue, and indeed already have, take pricing particularly in those emerging markets where we have to meet the transaction impact of foreign exchange because that's what translates into the operating earnings. We will, of course, be focused on our Funding the Growth programs, which again should benefit in 2015 from a more benign cost environment and, of course, we have our restructuring program. So as we begin 2015, we feel good with the expansion target of plus 50 to 100 basis points on gross margin, stepping its way up through the year. Now when you come back to the top line of the company, I think the fourth quarter played out organically pretty much the way we expected it. We see the destocking in China behind us, and that's way we see the 6% organic there and indeed organic growth in the country itself. In terms of Brazil, we said that we would still be working through the destocking in the fourth quarter that, that would be completed in the fourth quarter and then we would move into 2015 and indeed that has been the case. But if you step back and kind of take a look at where is the consumer, we continue to see for our categories that in North America, category growth, and again I'm talking our categories, is between 1% and 2% as we've said on the last call, it is edging wildly up to the upper end of that 1% and 2% range. Europe continues to be more [ph] between 0 and 1%. And across the emerging markets, we continue to feel comfortable with the mid single-digit local currency value growth rates for our categories. So that's the environment we see in 2015, with China and Brazil now behind us.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll move on to our next question from Dara Mohsenian from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll move on to our next question from Dara Mohsenian from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ian, pricing is generated pretty significantly sequentially in Q4 and it was a big driver of your organic sales growth acceleration in both emerging markets and globally. So I guess the want to get an update on your view the competitive environment here a
componenttext: Ian, pricing is generated pretty significantly sequentially in Q4 and it was a big driver of your organic sales growth acceleration in both emerging markets and globally. So I guess the want to get an update on your view the competitive environment here and your ability to sustain that level of pricing going forward with lower oil cost and flat commodities overall. Where you can get good incremental pricing with some of the incremental FX pressures you are seeing. And then also in Q4 on a-related note, how much of the Latin American price increase was related to Venezuela and Argentina?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we have demonstrated fairly consistently an ability to deliver pricing to offset the transaction impact of foreign exchange. I think we've demonstrated that in the fourth quarter. And we expect to continue to price as we have already done in
componenttext: Yes. I think we have demonstrated fairly consistently an ability to deliver pricing to offset the transaction impact of foreign exchange. I think we've demonstrated that in the fourth quarter. And we expect to continue to price as we have already done in some parts of the world. So pricing will be a factor in growth and in our gross margin expansion plans for 2015. And we believe, as we indeed already have, that we will be able to realized that. And I go back to the fourth quarter and say that was a fairly meaningful step-up in pricing in those emerging markets and yet we still had a balance between volume growth and pricing growth. Now when you turn to Latin America, the need for pricing again is driven by foreign exchange. And if you look at Latin America, overall, we took pricing in the fourth quarter and you see pricing up literally across the geography. From Mexico through Central America, Byron the group, Brazil and the Southern. So we took pricing across the Board. In Venezuela as we told you on the last call, we, along with our 2 principal multinational competitors and a large local player down there, on price control categories, got approval to increase pricing. And so we, along with everyone else, increased pricing in Venezuela. And that will roll forward into 2015. But again, you look at Asia, you look at Africa, Eurasia, we're taking pricing in all parts of the world that are affected by foreign exchange.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we'll move to Chris Ferrara with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And next we'll move to Chris Ferrara with Wells Fargo.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ian, just a follow-up on that. I can appreciate you don't want to pick out exactly what Venezuela pricing is but they think the question on a lot of people's minds is just the Latin segment pricing and the resilience of volume even on a tough comp was ver
componenttext: Ian, just a follow-up on that. I can appreciate you don't want to pick out exactly what Venezuela pricing is but they think the question on a lot of people's minds is just the Latin segment pricing and the resilience of volume even on a tough comp was very impressive, that's very impressive. But I think we're all trying to figure out is it relates to the sustainability of it, was Venezuela and Argentina a disproportionate driver of that, right? In other words, can we feel comfortable with the assumption that you guys were able to hold volume very well across the segment broadly and the numbers are not necessarily's skewed by Venezuela and Argentina?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, clearly we've got more pricing in Venezuela because we have had no pricing for an extended period of years. So the answer there is clearly yes, as it was for everybody else that we compete with in that country. I think the more pertinent question is
componenttext: Yes, clearly we've got more pricing in Venezuela because we have had no pricing for an extended period of years. So the answer there is clearly yes, as it was for everybody else that we compete with in that country. I think the more pertinent question is our ability to maintain that pricing and continue to increase that pricing going forward and our view is yes, we can. And again, I come back to the fourth quarter, having taken pricing, we did see volume growth in all of that divisions. Now, of course, that step-up in Venezuelan pricing will ease off as we work our way through 2015 because of Venezuela is much more episodic than many of the other markets. So the answer is yes. And again, back to the consumer behavior, we've continued to see our categories hold in, in the emerging markets at mid-single digits. And remember, as you will see when we file our K, for us, 2014, Venezuela continues to represent about 3% of the company's worldwide sales and only about 1% of the operating margin.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to Olivia Tong of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And next we'll go to Olivia Tong of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about consumer consumption levels. Do you think that the current growth rates that you're posting our in line with where consumer consumption is right now? And on top of that, how do you think about your levels of inventory levels at r
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about consumer consumption levels. Do you think that the current growth rates that you're posting our in line with where consumer consumption is right now? And on top of that, how do you think about your levels of inventory levels at retail? And I also want to touch a little bit on the elasticity of demand in your categories because in the past you said that consumers understand pricing due to 2 FX. But at what point does that equation start to potentially break down because this quarter, you obviously a big acceleration in price and volume really didn't accelerate all that much but can you help us understand the analytics to measure that you don't potentially go overboard on pricing and what do you consider too much? I guess volume actually decelerates to the point where you're seeing negatives, would you consider that to go too foregin? Clearly, I'm painting specifically about Latin America.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well clearly, Olivia, as I'm sure all other companies do, we do considerable work to balance data if in the short-term volume impact of the pricing we take. I come back and say that we saw volume growth in all of our emerging markets, even with the s
componenttext: Yes, well clearly, Olivia, as I'm sure all other companies do, we do considerable work to balance data if in the short-term volume impact of the pricing we take. I come back and say that we saw volume growth in all of our emerging markets, even with the stepped up pricing we took in the fourth quarter. So we think we have a handle on it, and we think again, remember that types of products we are selling, that we can take the pricing necessary to offset the foreign exchange impacts and continue to balance between volume and price. And indeed, volume slows a little bit when you take the pricing but then that balance comes back. No, on retail inventory, you may remember, we were the first to talk about the destocking in China. And I think that we try to be very transparent about what we saw unfolding in the marketplace. This China destocking is behind us, and I said on the last call that we expect Brazil to work through in the fourth quarter. And it has done. We track not only retail inventory, we track inventory with all of our distributors country-by-country. And we have parameters that actually relate to the return on invested capital that his repair gets in terms of the inventory levels that they would hold. So we have a very clear view on that inventory. And we have a very sharp focus on making sure that it is not at least by our actions, out of balance. What we saw in Brazil and China was a marketplace destocking because of the slowdown in the categories. So I think you can feel confident that we have very much control on that inventory. And remember, as we talked about when we went through those subprime years, in difficult times, products in our categories, if you will, become the simple luxuries that consumers can afford. So the behavior of using these products does not go away when times get slightly tougher.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we have John Faucher from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And next we have John Faucher from JPMorgan.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to follow-up on some of the guidance commentary in terms of I think you said that 10% is the translation number. So can you talk a little bit about the -- the transaction piece is a little bit different now given what we've seen in terms
componenttext: So I just wanted to follow-up on some of the guidance commentary in terms of I think you said that 10% is the translation number. So can you talk a little bit about the -- the transaction piece is a little bit different now given what we've seen in terms of the move in the euro and some of the other more developed markets currencies, which obviously are negatives. So can you talk about sort of how much of the transaction piece maybe you're not going to cover. And can you get pricing in developed markets to cover some of the transnational peace. Is that a possibility even or is that something we basically say you know what, we're going to eat that impact given where the market is right now?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, John. Let me just complete what Bina said. I mean so when I think about foreign exchange as a headwind, yes, the translation impact is 10% on the bottom line on the top line, we see it's going to be about 7% to 7.5% of the year. So that just
componenttext: Yes, thanks, John. Let me just complete what Bina said. I mean so when I think about foreign exchange as a headwind, yes, the translation impact is 10% on the bottom line on the top line, we see it's going to be about 7% to 7.5% of the year. So that just gives you the breadth of that. In terms of the transaction impact, that is embedded into our guidance on gross margin being out 50 to 100 basis points per that transaction impact, whether it's the balance sheet aspect of payables in the short-term or the more substantive foreign exchange impact on raw materials or imported finished goods in the medium term, that hits the gross margin squarely. And if you don't recover that, you can't deliver an operating return. So all of of our guidance is assuming our ability to offset that transaction impact. Now remember, offsetting that transaction impact is not just a function of this price increases in any given market place. It can be benefited from mix. It can be benefited from different types of promotional activity that elevate the ASP. We have the benefit of our funding-the-growth program. We have the benefit of the global growth and restructuring program that we have underway. And as I said at the beginning, the benefit of a more benign commodity environment, especially in the area of. If you look in Europe and North America, these price increases are difficult to accomplish. But you saw in the Europe, terrific margin expansion this year. So there, it's going to be some of the other techniques that I think are going to continue to drive gross margin most especially our efforts, the global growth and efficiency program and what we can do with our promotional efficiencies as we go forward rather than list price increases but that's the way we plan the year, John.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we have Joe Altobello with Raymond James.
componenttext: And next we have Joe Altobello with Raymond James.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to shift gears a bit to SG&A and want to put the 50 basis points of overhead savings in some context because it seems like it's a bit of an outlier compared to the last few quarters. First, what was the FX impact on SG&A in the quarter? And ho
componenttext: I just want to shift gears a bit to SG&A and want to put the 50 basis points of overhead savings in some context because it seems like it's a bit of an outlier compared to the last few quarters. First, what was the FX impact on SG&A in the quarter? And how sustainable is the 50 basis points you saw in the fourth quarter? And how should we think about advertising next year? It came down about 60 basis points in '14. It was down both absolutely and as percent of sales. I'm curious how you think about that as you're shifting dollars from advertising to promotion in 2015?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well let me start with the advertising, Joe. So as we have said for quite a considerable time, the advertising is a combination of what we all grew up with, which is the traditional media and promotion. And we have always balanced that in terms of th
componenttext: Yes, well let me start with the advertising, Joe. So as we have said for quite a considerable time, the advertising is a combination of what we all grew up with, which is the traditional media and promotion. And we have always balanced that in terms of the traditional with the in-store activity that we undertake during the year. So if you look at the balance, in fact in the quarter, our total commercial investment was up as it was for the year. Interestingly, many of our competitors in many large markets around the world eased back on their traditional advertising spend. So in many of those markets actually, our competitive pressure was actually strengthened. Now as we think about 2015, in terms of that traditional market of advertising and promotion, we are planning for that to increase absolutely and as a percentage to sales. And as we have always done, we will continue to balance that as the year unfolds. So we feel very much that the advertising is where we needed to be and I think, candidly, Joe, when you look at the results in the fourth quarter, we've got a 6% organic growth rate and delivered a pretty robust bottom line. And, of course, it's that kind of sustainable top and bottom line growth that we are focused on. You know relative to the overhead, ForEx isn't much of an impact. We continue to expect to make progress in terms of overheads because the Global Growth and Efficiency Program is largely focused in that area rather than gross margin this time around. And again, as Bina said, we were ahead of delivery of that program in 2014 and we will continue to make progress in 2015.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll now move on to Bill Schmitz with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll now move on to Bill Schmitz with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to figure out the organic topline guide. You gave market growth rates, is that going to be your growth rate as well? Because like if I weight sort of 45% developed, 55% emerging and we assume that the developed this is 1% and 2% and emergi
componenttext: I'm just trying to figure out the organic topline guide. You gave market growth rates, is that going to be your growth rate as well? Because like if I weight sort of 45% developed, 55% emerging and we assume that the developed this is 1% and 2% and emerging's5% to 6%. That kind of gets you like a 3% to 5% range. Is that the right way to think about it or do you think you're going to continue your market share and growth in the market?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've been pleased with our market share progress, Joe, and, of course, as Joe, Bill, everyone's Joe. Obviously we have some new businesses that we're entering, whether it's the intimate product, whether it's new markets with Sanex and indeed some of the
componenttext: We've been pleased with our market share progress, Joe, and, of course, as Joe, Bill, everyone's Joe. Obviously we have some new businesses that we're entering, whether it's the intimate product, whether it's new markets with Sanex and indeed some of the new geographies we have around the world like Nigeria, like Iran, like stepping up our position in Bangladesh. But we continue to be comfortable with that 4% to 7% range that we have talked about, which we think adequately reflects the volatility that it is in our world. If you take 2013 as a year, our full year, we came in about 6%. If you look at 2014 now was a full year, we came in organic growth about 5%. So we think that 4% to 7% range remains reasonable. And indeed, that is what we're planning against. And I'm sorry about the name, slip up.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we have Michael Steib of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And next we have Michael Steib of Credit Suisse.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question really relates to the U.S. environment, really. You said that U.S. category growth is edging towards the upper end of the 1% and 2% range yet pricing in your categories continues to be down due to the promotional activities. Given the commodit
componenttext: My question really relates to the U.S. environment, really. You said that U.S. category growth is edging towards the upper end of the 1% and 2% range yet pricing in your categories continues to be down due to the promotional activities. Given the commodity costs tailwind even if it's marginal as you're going to experienced next year, do you see the promotional environment remain broadly similar levels going forward? Or should I say intensify from here?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I think, Michael, our assumption is that it will continue pretty much at as it has been. When you look at 2014, you might say that some of the, shall we say, naked pricing pressure has come off but we definitely saw in the North American environment,
componenttext: Well I think, Michael, our assumption is that it will continue pretty much at as it has been. When you look at 2014, you might say that some of the, shall we say, naked pricing pressure has come off but we definitely saw in the North American environment, couponing, both in terms of the number of coupons dropped and you know that's a large part of U.S. promotional activity and works its way through the income statement and price. But couponing volume and couponing values, both stepped-up substantially in 2014. And we expect that will continue in 2015. Now in part coupons great trials for new products so that's quite healthy. So you'll see some bumps I guess, quarter-by-quarter because of the because of that. So we're assuming that competitive of environment in our categories at least will continue as we've seen it perhaps with more emphasis towards couponing.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we'll move to Connie Maneaty with BMO Capital.
componenttext: And next we'll move to Connie Maneaty with BMO Capital.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping that you would discuss some metrics that have improved in the areas where you've completed the move to your new hubbing.
componenttext: I was hoping that you would discuss some metrics that have improved in the areas where you've completed the move to your new hubbing.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think we've -- the new areas really -- we're back up. I mean, we have had hubbing operations in parts of our world for a long period of time and I think it we've talked about better relative to the Latin America when I talked about the groups we h
componenttext: Okay. I think we've -- the new areas really -- we're back up. I mean, we have had hubbing operations in parts of our world for a long period of time and I think it we've talked about better relative to the Latin America when I talked about the groups we had there and the activity that we took their your the next be tranche if you will of hubbing has been Europe. And in that environment, we have both accomplished and delivered the savings and the efficiency that we were looking for. And now the market level activity begins and the next leg of our journey now will be to get the accrued benefits of having the work with Shared Service Centers. And I guess frankly most importantly, of all, with that, focus and the ability to sharpen our investment behind the businesses as you saw in the release and in Bina's commentary, market shares in our principal categories are, and that in a slow growth European environment is ultimately what underpins I think our ability to continue to deliver organic growth in that part of the world, which when you think about why we prioritize Europe first from the Global Growth and Efficiency point of view was the objective of the exercise.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we have Bill Chappell of SunTrust.
componenttext: And next we have Bill Chappell of SunTrust.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ian, can you just kind of help us work through as we look at oil kind of dropping to where it did in the fourth quarter, how that works through your P&L over the next 12 months? I mean in terms of the diesel or just straight oil or resin and then maybe pe
componenttext: Ian, can you just kind of help us work through as we look at oil kind of dropping to where it did in the fourth quarter, how that works through your P&L over the next 12 months? I mean in terms of the diesel or just straight oil or resin and then maybe percentages, if you can, do we see 50% of the benefit by the first half or do we really not see it until the second half? Just trying to get a gauge of how it really influences the business and how low it takes to influence the business.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well as you heard from many, there is a lag, things in life have a way of going up quicker than they  become down. If you take all you oil the most immediate benefit you get tends to be in freight because that price is quite quickly. And so we've got
componenttext: Yes. Well as you heard from many, there is a lag, things in life have a way of going up quicker than they  become down. If you take all you oil the most immediate benefit you get tends to be in freight because that price is quite quickly. And so we've got a little bit of the benefit in the fourth quarter, very modest, and we expect that to benefit us starting in this quarter in 2015. When you talk about the flow-through benefits of the resin impact in the other material impact, that will start to benefit us towards the end of the first half partly related to it working through the system, partly related to our own inventory levels. You have to work those through before you get the benefit, which is why we make a point that as we build to that 50 to 100 basis points gross margin improvement, it is going to build across the year because the commodity benefits will really start flowing in, in the second quarter.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we will go to Bill Strachan from
componenttext: And next we will go to Bill Strachan from

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just ask a follow-up to that last question, where are you budgeting oil for '15? And then just shifting gears, could you talk a bit about your thoughts on the share gains that you've seen from some of your euro-based competitors over the last
componenttext: I wanted to just ask a follow-up to that last question, where are you budgeting oil for '15? And then just shifting gears, could you talk a bit about your thoughts on the share gains that you've seen from some of your euro-based competitors over the last 3 to 5 years? And your views on pending of some sort of incremental spend that we're going to have given current exchange rates, as well as potentially reversing some of those share gains that you've had sort of just broadly how do you think about more able-bodied competitive landscape from some of those companies?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- in terms of the oil, we actually budgeted oil at about $60. So obviously, if it stays stays at the current level, we will pick up, we will pick up a little bit more. We will have to see how all of that works through across the year. In terms of
componenttext: Yes, we -- in terms of the oil, we actually budgeted oil at about $60. So obviously, if it stays stays at the current level, we will pick up, we will pick up a little bit more. We will have to see how all of that works through across the year. In terms of European-based competitors, if you mean from a foreign exchange point of view, we're all managing in a world. And we all have different parts of the world, and we all have growth ambitions in those different parts of the world. We have, we think, been quite responsible with the benefit of the Global Growth and Efficiency Program in Europe in making sure that our commercial investments, including traditional advertising and promotion, are appropriate for both the European category growth rate and the competitors we meet in Europe. If we see things change, and we think we need to be more responsive, back to this notion of agility and balance, we will take the appropriate action. But right now, we are quite comfortable with our European growth and with our investments stance there relative to both the categories and our competitors.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we will go to Ali Dibadj with Bernstein.
componenttext: And next we will go to Ali Dibadj with Bernstein.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just a couple of quick follow-ups. 1 is -- and I'm sorry you might have said this but jump for a second if you would quantify actually the Venezuela impact on your growth rate because even it's 3% of sales you said, price, mix the best we can tell put
componenttext: So just a couple of quick follow-ups. 1 is -- and I'm sorry you might have said this but jump for a second if you would quantify actually the Venezuela impact on your growth rate because even it's 3% of sales you said, price, mix the best we can tell put that together might be 0.5 to 2 points of your 6 point growth. So if you have, quantify that, I apologize but if you could say that again. And I do  want to go back to this ad spend being down 8% so below 10% for you, which is something I haven't seen in 2009 and to your point, I don't think it's unique to you guys and a lot of the companies in this sector are trying to to your point, balance the above-the-line versus the below-the-line ad spend and the risk to the brand and so I'm trying to get a sense from you, because that doesn't show in 1 quarter, right? So the risk to the brand as you go forward and how do you think about that growth to net versus pure ad spend spend and what the right balance is?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Weld no, even if you did drop-off, Ali, we didn't provide that information on Venezuela and we won't now. The point I did make relative to Venezuela in the Latin America is that we feel pricing across Latin America in the fourth quarter in the case o
componenttext: Yes. Weld no, even if you did drop-off, Ali, we didn't provide that information on Venezuela and we won't now. The point I did make relative to Venezuela in the Latin America is that we feel pricing across Latin America in the fourth quarter in the case of Venezuela, yes, it was episodic as we said in the third quarter, it would be because we haven't had pricing think for several years. That same episodic benefit also benefited our principal multinational competitors who got the same government approvals on key categories for them at exactly the same time as we got ours. And indeed the local competitor was granted pricing as well. So everybody benefited from pricing in Venezuela. But the point to make is we took pricing across the Board and in an environment where everybody but was getting pricing our global growth rate was in the 6%. In terms of the advertising, yes, you're right. 1 has to be conscious about the brand health as we call it. I will say that the kind of model that perhaps many of us grew up with where what was accounted for in trade spending was inherently bad and only the so-called below-the-line spending was good, I think those days are gone. I think one's ability to take Hispanic consumers in the U.S. that you can reach with in-store activity that may have a component of price but might be much more driven by a coupon that is regionally dropped trucked to high population areas. This kind of techniques are now available and it weren't available before. And you can measure them, retailers can handle different configurations to put them at work with the consumer. But coming back to the brands, we do to tracking work and our tracking work around the world shows that if you take out Oral Care business around the world, the health is very, very good of those brands. So by all means, we track it. Sometimes from a short-term point of view, if couponing or other activity steps up, you have no option at least in part to participate. But I think we've been 1 of the loudest voices, I at least I hope so, in saying that we much prefer to compete in an environment of innovation with marketing support then price motion. But we don't see weakness in brand health. That is something, of course, we have and we'll continue to track.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to Lauren Lieberman of Barclays.
componenttext: And next we'll go to Lauren Lieberman of Barclays.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 things. 1 was to follow-up on the conversation about in-store spend versus traditional advertising. Is it fair then to summarize kind of the environment you're seeing right now to say that in the regions where you've had more in-store spend, more p
componenttext: Just 2 things. 1 was to follow-up on the conversation about in-store spend versus traditional advertising. Is it fair then to summarize kind of the environment you're seeing right now to say that in the regions where you've had more in-store spend, more promotion, it's not necessarily because of negative flareups in the competitive environment. It's a little bit more choiceful on how to best reach the consumer for a given activity that you guys have slated? Or is there in fact that step-up in the negative promotional environment currently?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say it's m ore of the former, Lauren. And these are techniques that our Colgate business planning and so on that we have learned to be efficient with so it's choiceful. But I will also have to say take an environment like the United States, there'
componenttext: I would say it's m ore of the former, Lauren. And these are techniques that our Colgate business planning and so on that we have learned to be efficient with so it's choiceful. But I will also have to say take an environment like the United States, there's no question that, that couponing environment has become more competitive. And we have correspondingly become more competitive in that environment. But if I took on overall stance, I would say as we have been saying for a time, that it is choiceful we techniques that we think not only reach the consumer about actually strengthens the equity of our brands over time.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And now we'll move on to Javier Escalante from Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: And now we'll move on to Javier Escalante from Consumer Edge Research.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question has to do with the 2012 Restructuring Program that was expanded to the savings target to 390. It seems to me like only 1/3 of the savings has been accrued up to now. So I'd like to understand how much of savings will accelerate in the next cou
componenttext: My question has to do with the 2012 Restructuring Program that was expanded to the savings target to 390. It seems to me like only 1/3 of the savings has been accrued up to now. So I'd like to understand how much of savings will accelerate in the next couple of years in order to hit the $390 million target? And if you could help us understand what kind of activities are going to happen. Is this more hubbing like the 1 you did in Europe? Or is it manufacturing facilities being up in Asia. Help us understand physically what activities are going to take place that would help the savings ramp up in the next 2 years, okay?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, first thing to say, Javier, the program is very much on track. Indeed as Bina said, our performance in 2014 was up. If you look at our so far savings against the total, we're running about half accrued. So it's not 1/3. And if you look at the activit
componenttext: Yes, first thing to say, Javier, the program is very much on track. Indeed as Bina said, our performance in 2014 was up. If you look at our so far savings against the total, we're running about half accrued. So it's not 1/3. And if you look at the activity going forward, yes, it is in the same areas that we had very much spoken to in the beginning. So it is the hubbing. It is what we are doing with our facilities and it is the expanded use of the Colgate business service centers. And we're very excited by it because we think is we have now seen in Europe, not only does it bring you the immediate term savings but it makes you operate smarter and faster and in a more efficient manner. So we like it not just as a Global Growth and Efficiency Program but because we think it ultimately gets us organizationally to a better place from an operating point of view.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to Caroline Levy of CLSA.
componenttext: And next we'll go to Caroline Levy of CLSA.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've got a question about Russia and another on Mexico. On Russia, I guess to describe it as pretty chaotic. And I'm just wondering how much of your pricing were able to take in the fourth quarter and how much you think you still need to take and whether
componenttext: I've got a question about Russia and another on Mexico. On Russia, I guess to describe it as pretty chaotic. And I'm just wondering how much of your pricing were able to take in the fourth quarter and how much you think you still need to take and whether you think whether they might build drop-off quite meaningfully? And secondly, on Mexico, both Kimberly and Procter had very difficult years trading in Mexico and they, to some extent, blamed the higher consumer tax. Are you seeing any slowdown in demand or did you see any slowdown? Do see any pickup we woke how what's going on in Mexico for you guys?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mexico hasn't changed for us. We certainly didn't see a 20% decline there, nor did we see 20% decline in China so no, that environment hasn't really changed for us. Russia, Russia for us is still a relatively modest part of our business between 1% and 2%.
componenttext: Mexico hasn't changed for us. We certainly didn't see a 20% decline there, nor did we see 20% decline in China so no, that environment hasn't really changed for us. Russia, Russia for us is still a relatively modest part of our business between 1% and 2%. And chaotic maybe overstating it, but it is indeed difficult and it is likely to become more difficult. We have before at the end the '80s and indeed the Senior Executives that is living again now. So we know the actions to take from a structural cost point of view, and we're taking those actions and, of course, we are taking pricing, and we are transferring funds, and we are watching closely distributors and wholesalers. So we are very much managing Russia from a containment point of view. But you know we're very close to our businesses, so we believe we have a good handle on it and interestingly, shares are up. So maybe cold, but they're up.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our final question from Jason English from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our final question from Jason English from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've got a couple of follow-up questions.
componenttext: I've got a couple of follow-up questions.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible]
componenttext: [indiscernible]

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That seems right. 1 on the commercial dynamics. On P&G's conference call, they referenced expectation of gaining 400 basis points of margin gains, constant currency or even currency loaded either Brazil and India. Hard to see how to get that without pulli
componenttext: That seems right. 1 on the commercial dynamics. On P&G's conference call, they referenced expectation of gaining 400 basis points of margin gains, constant currency or even currency loaded either Brazil and India. Hard to see how to get that without pulling some of the money they put in the market back out. So are you seeing the promotional in densities in those markets? And then secondly, gross margins. I just want to talk a little bit more deeply on the answer to the question earlier. You're signaling sort of neutral commodities maybe even a little bit of fear of it favorability with oil so to steady old-line on price, continued productivity you do the math on that even if you assume transactional headwinds become more substantial in other words this quarter it's still hard not to see a path at least to 150 basis points gross margin expansion. So what am I missing there?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: About 50 basis points. I think. If you take India and the promotional intensity, actually India from Proctor's point of view was never particularly intense in our categories. So if we look at India to not talk about the market share, we're approaching 55
componenttext: About 50 basis points. I think. If you take India and the promotional intensity, actually India from Proctor's point of view was never particularly intense in our categories. So if we look at India to not talk about the market share, we're approaching 55 and the competitor in question has about 1.7 share. And our business there continues to be quite strong. In terms of Brazil, I would say yes. The promotional intensity has dropped off a little bit in Brazil, which is a good thing. On gross margin, Jason, and I'm sorry with a glib response. But the gross margin is really 1 of phasing because as I tried to explain earlier, we think that gross margin expansion is very much going to build across the year because although we see the headline lowering the commodity costs and certainly oil, the work of that from our inventory point of view to its effect on resins, bottles, et cetera will take some time to be seen. And on the flip side, the transaction impact when ForEx goes, that hits you straight away, whether it's the stuff you have to pay and your payables, whether it's the dollar-denominated raw materials that replace that which you are now having to pay for. So that's immediate. And go we in that on the gross margin takes a little bit more time. So I do think we'll end next year in a strength and position gross margin wise but it really has also to do with facing. So I believe these are all I've been at this for were all the questions we had?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sir.
componenttext: Yes, sir.

componenttext: Okay, so well thanks very much for catching up with us today and a special thank you to all the Colgate folk that make it happen. Bye bye.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Colgate-Palmolive Company Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded and is being simulcast live at www.colgatepalmolive.com.Today's conference call will include for
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Colgate-Palmolive Company Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded and is being simulcast live at www.colgatepalmolive.com.
Today's conference call will include forward-looking statements. These statements are made on the basis of our views and assumptions as of this time and are not guarantees of future performance.
Actual events or results may differ materially from these statements. So for information about certain factors that could cause such differences, investors should consult our most recent annual report on Form 10-K filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and available on our website, including the information set forth under the captions Risk Factors and Cautionary Statement on forward-looking statements.
This conference call will also include a discussion of non-GAAP financial measures, which differ from our results prepared in accordance with GAAP. We will discuss organic sales growth, which is net sales growth, excluding foreign exchange, acquisitions and divestitures.
We will also discuss gross profit, gross profit margin, SG&A, SG&A as a percent of net sales, operating profit, operating profit margin, net income and earnings per share on a diluted basis, excluding the impact of the items described in the press release.
A full reconciliation with the corresponding GAAP measures is included in the press release and is posted in the For Investors section of our website at www.colgatepalmolive.com.
Just a reminder, there may be a slight delay before the question-and-answer session begins due to the Web simulcast.
Now for opening remarks, I'd like to turn the call over to the Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Bina Thompson. Please go ahead, Bina.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cathy, and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our fourth quarter earnings release conference call.With me this morning are Ian Cook, Chairman, President and CEO; Dennis Hickey, CFO; Victoria Dolan, Corporate Controller; and Elaine Paik, Tre
componenttext:
Thanks, Cathy, and good morning, everybody, and welcome to our fourth quarter earnings release conference call.
With me this morning are Ian Cook, Chairman, President and CEO; Dennis Hickey, CFO; Victoria Dolan, Corporate Controller; and Elaine Paik, Treasurer.
We're pleased to exit 2014 with organic sales up 6% as compared to the fourth quarter of 2013, which was the strongest quarter of last year. Our market shares are strong around the world as you will hear in a moment. As always, innovation has been critical to our success and we're excited about our pipeline looking forward to 2015 and beyond. 
In many markets, macroeconomic challenges persist. And of course, foreign exchange has been and will continue to be a considerable headwind as translation alone is projected to impact EPS in 2015 over 10% at current foreign exchange rates. That makes us even more pleased to be able to deliver continued organic sales growth and positive results on the bottom line. 
While our gross margin was down in the quarter due to very significant transaction costs, we believe that we'll see an improving trend as we move through 2015 with a more benign raw material cost environment and pricing taken to offset the impact of rising transaction costs related to foreign exchange. Our funding-the-growth program is as robust as ever and our Global Growth and Efficiency Program is on track. Savings generated in 2014 related to the Global Growth and Efficiency Program were over $100 million after tax and above the top end of our projected range. Overhead expenses are down in the quarter due to tight controls in all divisions and savings from our Global Growth and Efficiency Program. Our total commercial spending also increased in support of both existing and new products. 
We think we're well poised to meet the challenges we face as we enter 2015. We believe our strong balance sheet and a solid cash generation should keep us in good stead. 
So turning to North America. We're very pleased with our progress here. Innovation is contributing to organic sales growth and we have more plans for this year. In the fourth quarter, in the U.S., our market share increased year-to-date in toothpaste and manual toothbrushes and was even with the prior year in mouthwash. Results were strong across our portfolio in toothpaste. Our Colgate Total toothpaste share remains over 10%, supported by a graphic refresh, a relaunch of Colgate Total Advanced Whitening and the boost provided by our companion, Colgate Total Lasting White mouthwash. The Colgate Optic White franchise is also doing well as the superpremium line is driving incrementality with its year-to-date toothpaste share up from 5.3% to 5.6%. And as you know, we also launched Colgate Enamel Health Toothpaste and toothbrushes in the second half of 2014. It's off to a strong start and our overall toothpaste share is up 1.4% in the 3 months after its launch as compared to the 3 months prior. 
In the mouthwash category, our year-to-date share is up more than a full point while our 2 major competitors' full year shares declined, with excellent results from Colgate Total Lasting White mouthwash. Our fabric conditioner business continues to perform well. Both for the full year and the quarter, our market share is up over a full point to a new record, close to 20% of the overall market and as you know, these products are primarily sold in Hispanic markets. And as you would expect, we have more innovation slated for 2015 with a full grid plan for the first quarter. In toothpaste, we're launching Colgate Optic White, Express White toothpaste. This innovation provides whiter teeth in just 3 days simply by brushing with best results after 4 weeks of brushing as directed. It's Colgate's fastest whitening toothpaste and is enamel safe for daily use. In the mouthwash category, we're launching Colgate Total Gum Health mouthwash. It provides advanced gum protection for 45% stronger, healthier gums versus a none antibacterial mouthwash. It fights plaque between teeth and along the gum line and kills 99% of germs on contact with 12-hour protection against bacteria that cause gingivitis. In the toothbrush category, we're launching Colgate Sensitive Toothbrush Plus Sensitivity Relief Pen. Using the same innovative pen application technology that has been so successful in the whitening segment. The pen utilizes our patented Pro-Argin Technology to deliver sensitivity relief 24/7 with continued use and goes right to the source of the pain. To rekindle momentum in the dish liquid category, we're launching a premium priced Palmolive multiservice, which is specially formulated to kill bacteria on dishes and hard, nonporous kitchen surfaces. And on the value side, we're launching Ajax all-in-one dish liquid, which has a new formula with 10% more cleaning ingredients than before. And to further our success in the fabric conditioner category, we're launching Suavitel fragrance pro with a proprietary scent system, which provides 5x longer lasting fragrance compared with using detergent alone as well as Suavitel Fast Dry dryer sheet, which helps clothes dry 30% faster than using detergent alone. 
Turning then to Europe/South Pacific. We enjoyed another quarter of organic sales growth in this region with a slight acceleration in volume from the third quarter. Our commercial hubbing activities, part of our Global Growth and Efficiency Program, are now complete and were implemented with very little disruption. In fact in the quarter, virtually all new hubs delivered positive organic sales growth. Innovation is critical in this part of the world and it continues to contribute to market share growth in a number of our categories. Our market shares across Europe are up year-to-date in toothpaste, manual toothbrush, battery toothbrush, mouthwash, liquid hand soap and dish liquid. Of note, all categories of our Sanex business has grown market share year-to-date; shower gel, liquid hand soap and underarm protection. Our launch of Colgate Maximum Cavity Protection plus Sugar Acid Neutralizer is now complete across the region with excellent share results in a number of markets. One of our first launch markets, Denmark, posted a 4.1% share in the most recent period and 2 larger more recent market launch markets, the U.K. and France, have already achieved 1.5% and 2% shares, respectively, in the most recent periods. 
Building on this success in 2015, we will continue full marketing support for the toothpaste along with a further rollout of a companion toothbrush and mouthwash. As I just mentioned, our Sanex business is performing well and we have some exciting new product activity to support further growth. Launching in the first quarter is Sanex ADVANCED, Sanex's first bodycare regimen developed with leading dermatologists. Available in 3 different formulations, the regimen will include a body lotion and hand cream to complement the body wash and deodorant. This is Sanex's first entry into the hand and body lotion category. The Sanex ADVANCED Dermo Repair bundle for dry skin with minor damage contains active restore complex and allantoin to restore pH balance and moisturization. The Sanex ADVANCED atopi [ph] derm bundle for extra try atopic skin contains skin-identical lipids and emollients to help restore the skin's protective barrier, sooth itchiness and control hypersensitivity, helping the skin to keep functioning normally. 
The Sanex Advanced Hydrate 24H bundle for very dry, dehydrated skin uses Ceragly Activ Technology in the shower gel and lotion, which has pseudo-ceramide and glycerine to maintain the skin's protective barrier by locking in the moisture. And in addition, we'll be launching Sanex in Poland, a new geography, which will provide incremental new business for us. 
Turning then to Latin America. Business across this region is solid. Organic sales growth accelerated from the prior 2 quarters in 2014 and while volume increased a modest 1% versus the year-ago period, this was on top of a very strong increase of 10% in the fourth quarter of 2013. Toothpaste shares are strong across the region. In Mexico, our most recent share is 80.8%, up 80 basis points from the year-ago period. Colgate Maximum Cavity Protection has achieved a 2% share in the most recent period. In Brazil in December, our toothpaste share reached 72.1% for the month, the highest share in the past 18 years. This is in spite of a lot of competitive activity. Our manual toothbrush business is performing well. In Mexico, we achieved a record share of 45% in the latest reading, while for the first time our major competitor dropped below the 40% share. Growth was across all retail environments, self-service stores, pharmacies and the indirect trade. We reached a record year-to-date share in Brazil as well with good growth in the superpremium segment with a 32.4% share of the market, the #1 position. In bar soaps, we've strengthened our leadership position across the region, up 0.5 point on a year-to-date basis to 29.7% with the most recent read at 29.9%. 
Innovation in both the Palmolive and Protex equities has contributed to this success. And in the Home Care category, our year-to-date regional market shares have increased in fabric conditioners up 50 basis points to 51.6% and in liquid cleaners, up 70 basis points to 36.3%. And we have more exciting new products planned for 2015 across all our categories. In the first quarter, specifically, we're excited about a new subcategory in the Protex body cleansing category, feminine intimate wash. Protex is a brand that's recognized as an expert in skin protection and this positioning should transfer readily into the intimate care sub category. It will be launched with a fully integrated marketing campaign, including a product website and endorsements from a well-known journalist.
