componenttext: We'll now go to Olivia Tong with Bank of America.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, just following up on John's question. Now the gross outlook while down from prior expectations and probably just fairly big acceleration in the second half and you mentioned plans for more pricing, so that's part of it. But can you talk through som
componenttext: First, just following up on John's question. Now the gross outlook while down from prior expectations and probably just fairly big acceleration in the second half and you mentioned plans for more pricing, so that's part of it. But can you talk through some of the other key drivers like funding-the-growth and some of the cost savings programs that'll help drive that meaningful improvement in the back half margins?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Olivia, clearly, well, it is -- it really is a combination of the factors that I raised before, which is more pricing, more funding the growth, more favorable underlying commodity pricing. And maybe a little bit of global growth and efficiency as wel
componenttext: Yes. Olivia, clearly, well, it is -- it really is a combination of the factors that I raised before, which is more pricing, more funding the growth, more favorable underlying commodity pricing. And maybe a little bit of global growth and efficiency as well. And then you maybe got the mix aspect of our business that could provide a factor as well. But the real drivers will be pricing, will be funding the growth, underlying commodity costs and maybe a touch from global growth and efficiency as we have seen before.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then why is there -- on North America, why does there seem to be more volatility on pricing in North America than any other -- than all your other regions? Because it was up last quarter and then it reversed to be down this quarter. So what's driving
componenttext: And then why is there -- on North America, why does there seem to be more volatility on pricing in North America than any other -- than all your other regions? Because it was up last quarter and then it reversed to be down this quarter. So what's driving that difference?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the biggest single difference, Olivia, is couponing. Couponing is a very effective draw mechanism in the U.S., used more in the U.S. than any other geography around the world. And of course, goes into trade spending. Bina mentioned some of the new pr
componenttext: Yes, the biggest single difference, Olivia, is couponing. Couponing is a very effective draw mechanism in the U.S., used more in the U.S. than any other geography around the world. And of course, goes into trade spending. Bina mentioned some of the new products we have been introducing. And we have obviously been trying to build trial of new -- those new products and therefore you invest in couponing. And you see it in the volume growth of the business. So you're always going to see North America is a little bit more lumpy quarter-on-quarter because of that difference in the go-to-market.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Mark Astrachan with Stifel.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Mark Astrachan with Stifel.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask sort of as you go around the world, which geographies are you seeing the most impact from the local regional competition? I guess how do you think about changes in go-to-market strategy to compensate, if any? Any sort of thoughts or curren
componenttext: I wanted to ask sort of as you go around the world, which geographies are you seeing the most impact from the local regional competition? I guess how do you think about changes in go-to-market strategy to compensate, if any? Any sort of thoughts or current updates on a different way of actually going to market? How are you embracing Internet where applicable and so forth?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say local competitors are a factor around the world. I guess they've been often discussed by several folk in China. Certainly, we see them in Latin America. And your best way of responding and the way we try to respond is to understand the co
componenttext: Yes, I would say local competitors are a factor around the world. I guess they've been often discussed by several folk in China. Certainly, we see them in Latin America. And your best way of responding and the way we try to respond is to understand the consumer and make sure that the innovation we are providing is competitive against the benefit or the product offering, the local competitor is providing. And then secondly, when you mentioned go-to-market, it is often the case with the local competitor that they have a particular infrastructure that can build down trade distribution and a lot of activity again at retail level and you just need to be effective in making sure that your products are available at an equal rate to that competitor and that you have the same degree of activity at retail level to compete with them. Now China is an interesting example where our market share over the last several years has gone up from 29% to 34%. One of that principal competitors has come down from 25% to under 14%, and another has come down from 12% to high single-digit and the local competitor has really taken the difference. So without making one example predictor for the world, I think it demonstrates we have managed to defend and continued to grow our business quite well. But it comes down to product offering and the strength of your go-to-market particularly downtrade and particularly activity at retail.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Javier Escalante with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: We'll now go to Javier Escalante with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Quick question with regards to Hill's. Very good number, this 7%. It seems like the growth, at least in your 10-Q, you say that the Prescription Diet category, more like the veterinary part of the business, it was the most meaningful contribution. I have
componenttext: Quick question with regards to Hill's. Very good number, this 7%. It seems like the growth, at least in your 10-Q, you say that the Prescription Diet category, more like the veterinary part of the business, it was the most meaningful contribution. I have expected because last year we had this problem the PetSmart specialty stores kind of outlets, that it would be the other way around. So if you can explain the dynamics of the pet food market with the entry of this Blue Buffalo as a publicly traded company, are they promoting more? How -- what is happening in the specialty stores? And how sustainable this growth is in the veterinarian channel?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The -- I guess the simple answer is they both grew. And the reason for the growth was driven by innovation, both on the Prescription Diet line and the Science Diet line. The appearance of the Blue Buffalo in the pet superstores is not a new thing. They ha
componenttext: The -- I guess the simple answer is they both grew. And the reason for the growth was driven by innovation, both on the Prescription Diet line and the Science Diet line. The appearance of the Blue Buffalo in the pet superstores is not a new thing. They have been there for a long while and our presence in those stores, our activities in those stores has not been affected. So we saw very good growth. And as we have tried to say several times on calls, one of the big differences we were striving for was a stream of innovation on Hill's so that it was not episodic, but that we have a flow of innovation, both on the client side business and the Prescription Diet business and we think we have that. I mean who couldn't love innovation that has enhanced appetite trigger built into it. I bet the pets go for that. So it's driven by innovation. Now where Blue Buffalo will be new is in the more therapeutic side of the business. They have announced 2 entries in only 2 segments, 1 is derm, 1 is gastrointestinal. You will remember from Bina's remarks that we are going to market with a very compelling gastrointestinal product right now with the Prescription Diet line. So I come back to the innovation. It's -- we think it's strong and we think it will see us well with our very elevated share with the vets, which as you rightly say, continue to grow in the second quarter. So we think we're well positioned with both, Javier.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll now take a question from Lauren Lieberman from Barclays.
componenttext: We'll now take a question from Lauren Lieberman from Barclays.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just -- a couple of things. One is -- I know it's very clear mathematically that the SG&A has to be sort of the plug with the lower gross margin outlook. But I was wondering if that is really sourced from the restructuring savings, if it's an accele
componenttext: I was just -- a couple of things. One is -- I know it's very clear mathematically that the SG&A has to be sort of the plug with the lower gross margin outlook. But I was wondering if that is really sourced from the restructuring savings, if it's an acceleration, what you're tapping into to be kind of able to offset some of the gross margin impact? And then the second thing was, is it reasonable to assume that some of the gross margin impact is just a timing issue like the pricing that will be coming through to the balance of the year, as you get into 2016, will kind of make up some of this incremental pressure you're seeing in commodities because of FX?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Would you repeat the second question, Lauren?
componenttext: Would you repeat the second question, Lauren?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sorry, I realized as I was talking, I was getting really unclear. So the transactional impact on commodity cost, which I think is sort of what you were saying in Venezuela. Is the time of the pricing the issue? That it's not that you're not going to
componenttext: Yes. Sorry, I realized as I was talking, I was getting really unclear. So the transactional impact on commodity cost, which I think is sort of what you were saying in Venezuela. Is the time of the pricing the issue? That it's not that you're not going to price to recover this incremental pressure, it's just you can't get it fast enough to cover the impact this year. But as you go into next year, it starts to catch up.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean correct. The -- we've always had this situation. I tried to say earlier in response to a question. In some cases, Russia would be a classic example where a crisis emerges, you take a very aggressive pricing and accept the fallout on the volume just
componenttext: I mean correct. The -- we've always had this situation. I tried to say earlier in response to a question. In some cases, Russia would be a classic example where a crisis emerges, you take a very aggressive pricing and accept the fallout on the volume just to stay stabilize the business. In other cases, you simply can't take pricing quickly enough and intelligently manage the balance between volume, price and therefore, the top line growth in response to transaction, which hits you the minute the exchange slides. So our pricing benefit from that will be progressive over the balance of the year. And you're correct, will continue into 2016. So as we look at the balance of the year, yes, it is to do with the Global Growth and Efficiency Program. And as I said, advertising will be broadly in line with last year. You may recall the last time we spoke from a ratio point of view, you may recall the last time we spoke, we talked about it being up. So heavily led by global growth and efficiency. And I think you could say, a moderation. Again, we still think by our share and our top line delivery competitive with a moderation in the advertising over the back half.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll now take Iain Simpson from SocGen.
componenttext: And we'll now take Iain Simpson from SocGen.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'd seen increased commodity volatility and also increased currency volatility of late. And you've sort of talked about how your attitudes to pricing and trade spend change in response to that. Have you seen anything unusual for many of your global compe
componenttext: We'd seen increased commodity volatility and also increased currency volatility of late. And you've sort of talked about how your attitudes to pricing and trade spend change in response to that. Have you seen anything unusual for many of your global competitors in how they prioritize the balance of their spending? Is the landscape moving more towards trade spend or advertising? Or if you could just give us some color on the dynamics there.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, first of all, it's a great name. The -- but in response to the question, as we answer the previous question, I would say from a global point of view, no substantial difference. I mean if you go country-by-country around the world, you see diffe
componenttext: Yes. Well, first of all, it's a great name. The -- but in response to the question, as we answer the previous question, I would say from a global point of view, no substantial difference. I mean if you go country-by-country around the world, you see different approaches from different competitors that you have to react to but no overarching strategy that sees a significant change. No.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Colgate-Palmolive Company Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded and is being simulcast live at www.colgatepalmolive.com.Today's conference will include forward-looking stateme
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Colgate-Palmolive Company Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded and is being simulcast live at www.colgatepalmolive.com.
Today's conference will include forward-looking statements. These statements are made on the basis of the company's views and assumptions as of the first time and are not guarantees of future performance. Actual events or results may differ materially from these statements.
So for information about certain factors that could cause such differences, investors should consult the company's report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and available on our website, including the information set forth under the captions Risk Factors and Cautionary Statements on Forward-Looking Statements.
This conference call will also include a discussion of a non-GAAP financial measures, which differ from our results prepared in accordance with GAAP. Colgate will discuss organic sales growth, which is net sales growth, excluding foreign exchange, acquisitions and divestitures.
We will also discuss gross profit, gross profit margin, SG&A, SG&A as a percentage of net sales, operating profits, operating profit margin, net income and earnings per share on a diluted basis, excluding the impact of items described in the press release. A full reconciliation of the corresponding GAAP measures is included in the press release and is posted in the For Investors sections of Colgate's website at www.colgatepalmolive.com.
Just a reminder, there may be a slight delay before the question-and-answer session begins due to the web simulcast.
Now for opening remarks, I would like to turn the call over to the Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Bina Thompson. Please go ahead, Bina.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter 2015 earnings conference call. With me this morning are Ian Cook, President, Chairman and CEO; Dennis Hickey, CFO; Victoria Dolan, Corporate Controller; and Elaine Paik, Treasu
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter 2015 earnings conference call. With me this morning are Ian Cook, President, Chairman and CEO; Dennis Hickey, CFO; Victoria Dolan, Corporate Controller; and Elaine Paik, Treasurer.
We're pleased with the continued solid organic sales growth, of course, negative foreign exchange continue to be a major challenge but as you'll hear, our market share as our strong and growing, one the best indications of the health of the business. Happily, gross profit margin increased in the quarter, as a result of our funding-the-growth initiatives, pricing actions and our Global Growth and Efficiency Program. Worldwide, our overhead cost are down on a dollar basis.
Now while reported advertising was down on a dollar basis, we think we're getting good results from the dollars we spend both in-store and out. Digital advertising is growing in fact, as an example, in Latin America, we are increasing our investment in digital to better reach our younger audiences as well as to drive engagement. And as we focus on developing strategic collaboration for partners such as Google and Facebook, we're better able to measure the results of our investments. Marketing mix model studies from several countries across Latin America show an ROI for digital investments that is 3 to 4x higher than TV, confirming this shift is right to drive our business.
Our balance sheet remains solid and we're making very good progress on working capital. So let's get right into the divisions, starting with the North America.
Innovation continues to fuel our success in North America. As mentioned in the press release, our market share are up year-to-date into toothpaste, manual toothbrushes, mouthwash, liquid hand soap, body wash and fabric conditioners. And this was true on a quarter-over-quarter comparison as well. At the same time, we've seen a decline in private label shares in many of our categories, indicating the consumers preference for branded products and the strength of our equities.
In the toothpaste category, the launch of Colgate Total Daily Repair supported by engaging media campaign and strong in-store shopper material has added incremental share to the baseline products. In the whitening segment, we offer a full range of products, toothpaste, toothbrushes and mouthwash. Our Colgate Optic White toothpaste has grown share from 2.4% in the third quarter of 2011 to a 5.7% share in the most recent quarter. 
Colgate Enamel Health has also seen good growth, increasing a full share point quarter-over-quarter. Another exciting opportunity is the sensitivity segment, where we are a strong #2 player. That segment has seen a compound growth of 7.7% over the last 4 years versus 2.8% for toothpaste overall. 
In the mouthwash category, where our share is up year-to-date 20 basis points, both Colgate Total for Gum Health and Colgate Enamel Health Mouthwash are picking up momentum. Our Colgate Total for Gum Health variant is the #1 new item in the leading retailer and receiving full support in store. 
In liquid hand soap, our year-to-date share is up almost a full point to a leading 30.6%, while private label products have declined almost 2 full points year-to-date, the lowest level in at least 5 years. 
Premium offerings such as Softsoap Fragrant Foaming Collection and hand soap offer distinctive benefits. Similarly, Softsoap fresh and body wash with real extract with the unique formula giving you healthy looking skin that glows, earlier this year has increased our share in that category by almost a full point year-to-date. 
Fabric conditioner has also continued to perform well. Suavitel Fragrance Pearls in wash scent boosters, which provide 5x longer lasting fragrance versus detergent alone, which we told you about last quarter have helped increase our national share almost a full point year-to-date, now approaching 20% of the market. 
More trial-focused programs are expected to drive further growth in the fourth quarter. Now as you'd expect, our new product is well populated and we will share with you some more exciting innovations slated for early 2016 on future calls. 
Turning now to Europe/South Pacific. Our business there is showing encouraging signs of recovery with innovation playing a critical role. Our market shares are up year-to-date in toothpaste, manual toothbrushes, body wash, shower gel, underarm protection and fabric conditioners. 
In toothpaste, we're very excited about the early successes of our loans of Colgate Max White Expert White toothpaste, the latest premium offering in this fast-growing segment. Launched in the U.K. in June, it achieved a 2.7% share in August and was named the best new toiletries launched for 2015 by one of our larger drug retailers. 
Two products under the Elmex brand developed specifically for the pharmacy channel, Elmex Sensitive Professional and Elmex Antiquaries Professional have driven our pharmacy share in France to a leadership position of 26.3% year-to-date and now ahead of the nearest competitor by 150 basis points. 
In manual toothbrushes, our leading market share in Europe is up 130 basis points year-to-date to 24.6%, with our nearest competitor down to 17.4%. Driving these excellent results has been the relaunch across the region of our Colgate 360° manual toothbrush line. Priced at the super premium tier, these brushes deliver superior cleaning for a whole mouth clean and have been supported by a full shopper program. 
We're also very encouraged by our launch of Sanex Advanced range of body washes, underarm protection and body and hand lotion. This innovation brings dermatological expertise for skin specific needs to a third growth pillar for Sanex, leading the brand towards a more professional approach in [indiscernible]. Early results are excellent. Since launch, Sanex is the fastest-growing brand in both body washes and underarms and in our top markets of France, Spain and the U.K., our market shares are up in both categories. 
In fabric conditioners, our market shares are up 20 basis points year-to-date to 24% across the European region with the most recent read at 24.5%. Contributing to this success is Soupline Fruity Sensations with a striking look and feel and new different and long-lasting fragrances. More innovation is found across our categories for the rest of this year and into 2016. Specifically, in Oral Care, we will be launching the Colgate Expert White Toothpaste and built-in Whitening Pen. As you know, that product form has helped drive our manual toothbrush share to record high tier in the U.S. 
In toothpaste, we will be launching Colgate Total Proof. This innovation uses breakthrough color change technology that turns the white paste into blue foam while brushing, giving consumers the confidence of the ultimate clean feeling. 
Turning then to Latin America. Business across the region is solid and [indiscernible] innovation has driven market share increases. Our regional market shares are up year-to-date in toothpaste, manual toothbrushes, mouthwash, toilet soap, liquids soap, hand dish and liquid cleaners. And even in the phase of some economic uncertainties in countries such as Brazil, our category still show solid local currency growth. 
Our regional toothpaste share is up 2 full points year-to-date to 78.2%. In Brazil, our market share is up 50 basis points year-to-date to 72%, the highest share in over 20 years and in the phase of continued heightened competitive activity. Colgate Total 12 relaunched in August with the positioning of protects 100% of the surfaces of the mouth. Now has an 18.5% share in the most recent period. 
In Mexico, our share is up 1 point year-to-date to 81.3% with the most recent read at 81.6%, while our major competitor shows continued share decline. 
Contributing to this success is our premium priced Colgate Luminos White Advanced, Colgate's most advanced whitening toothpaste formulated to intensify the whiteness of your teeth by 3 shades. 
In manual toothbrushes, our market share is up 230 basis points year-to-date to 45.4% with the most recent read at 49.8%. In Mexico, we recently reintroduced our Colgate 360° line with the new packaging structure with premium finishing and improved benefit communication, all mouth clean with 151% more bad breath bacteria removal. As a result, the Colgate 360° Equity is up 110 basis points year-to-date, reaching a record 11.1% share. 
Our leading year-to-date bar soap share is at 30.8% with the most recent read at 32%. Record high shares were achieved in Mexico, Colombia and Guatemala. And our 2 equities, Protex and Palmolive, continue to hold the #1 and 2 positions across the region. 
In Mexico, where we have a strong Home Care business, our results are excellent across the 3 subcategories, hand dish, liquid cleaners and fabric conditioners. Our market shares are up on a year-to-date basis, 230 feet, 40 and 150 basis points, respectively to 52.6%, 33.5% and 48.4%. 
So looking ahead, to further boost our leading manual toothbrush share, we are now in the process of launching Colgate Slim Soft White with 17 times slimmer tips, spiral drizzles will provide both whitening and deep yet, gentle cleaning. And innovation launching now in fabric conditioners is Suavitel goodbye rinse, the market-leading Suavitel with an improve no-rinse formula. And as you would expect, more innovation is planned for 2016 to continue the momentum in this region. 
Turning then to Asia. We're pleased with the strength of the business particularly in our 2 largest markets, China and India, which both delivered good volume growth. Category growth rates remain mid-single-digit in China while in India, our categories are growing as well. 
In India, our year-to-date toothpaste share is at almost 55% on a national basis and close to 59% in rural markets. Our market-leading manual toothbrush share is 43.6% year-to-date and our launch of Colgate Sensitive Pro-Relief Enamel Repair toothpaste while in its early days is doing well. 
Our Colgate 360° Charcoal Gold toothbrush launched earlier in other Asian markets is now contributing to the results in India. This successful innovation with antibacterial bristles provides a whole mouth clean and has achieved strong shares across the region in the most recent period, 1.4% in Hong Kong, 2.5% in the Philippines, 1.3% in Taiwan and almost 2% in Malaysia and has an incremental in each market. 
More innovation is slated for this quarter and beyond. In China, we will be launching 2 new products developed to appeal to local consumer preferences. Colgate Power White lemon salt toothpaste for freshness and whitening experience with lemon and sea salt flavor and Colgate 360° Gold Charcoal Ginseng Gum Care toothpaste, which contains ginseng essence and enhances the gum's power of defense. 
Two popular Colgate Total variants, Charcoal Deep Clean and Pro-Gum, will now be available in a gel format in addition to the paste. And in Thailand, in the Personal Care category, we're launching products for both men and women. For men, Protex Men 3-in-1, an all-in-one body cleansing solution with antibacterial protection. And for women, Protex Intimate, with antibacterial protection for long long-lasting freshness and well-being sensation everyday. 
Africa/Eurasia. As you know, several of our larger markets in Africa/Eurasia region had been facing major currency headwinds. Despite the pricing actions we have taken to combat the currency headwinds, our organic sales growth is holding it mid-single digits, market shares are increasing and successful innovation is fueling our growth. 
Our regional toothpaste share is up a full point year-to-date to almost 33%. In Russia, our share is up 230 basis points year-to-date to 34.2%, hitting a record share of 35.1% in the most recent period. 
We recently launched Colgate Maximum Cavity Protection with sugar acid neutralizer, which has already reached a 0.7% share year-to-date and contributed to the share gains. In South Africa, our share grew 150 basis points year-to-date to 50.2% , driven by new marketing campaigns behind Colgate Total. 
In toothbrushes, our share decline in only 1 country and was up in the majority of our markets. In Russia, where we achieved incremental listings in Russia's #1 retailer, our toothpaste -- toothbrush share grew 270 basis points year-to-date to 48.1% with the most recent read at 49.4%. 
And in Turkey, our share grew 10 basis points year-to-date to 28.6% with the most recent read at 29.7%. And in South Africa, our share was up 30 basis points year-to-date to 38.2% with the most recent read at 38.6%. 
Our bar soap business continued with strong momentum in our 2 biggest markets, Russia and South Africa. The recent introduction of Protex Men Power contributed to a regional share gain of 150 basis points year-to-date to almost 24%. More innovation is slated for this quarter. 
Across the region, we will be relaunching our base Colgate Sensitive toothpaste and our line of Plax mouthwash. In the Personal Care category, we will be launching a body wash occupying the new energizing segment for men's body wash, Palmolive Men Citrus Crush. It invites the consumer to experience an intense invigorating shower with Denbury and great food ingredients sourced from the substances of nature and a sparkling citrus fragrant to spoil the senses. 
And Hill's. Hill's delivered another solid quarter of organic sales growth with a good balance of volume and price. Here in the U.S., superstore retail consumption showed a good increase. Innovation across Hill's Prescription Diet and Hill's Science Diet as well as volume growth in our ideal balance brand contributed to our good results. 
Our Prescription Diet Metabolic canine and feline food continued to gain share around the world. Our new stores form has accelerated our growth in the wet segment. We continue to receive endorsement from key thought leaders. And the global rollout this year of Prescription Diet Metabolic Plus breakthrough dual-efficacy food with nutrition and clinically proven to address obesity and concurrent conditions, has added to the momentum of the business. 
It's now selling in 38 countries and has benefited from extensive sampling to drive awareness and trial. Our ongoing global integrated marketing campaign includes professional print, online media, in-clinic seminars and recommendation tools and testimonial videos to showcase efficacy. 
In our wellness business, one of our newer launches, Hill's Science Diet urinary and hairball control, is meeting with excellent results. The only wellness food that addresses the 2 most common conditions in healthy cat, it was among the top 3 we variance in the U.S. market during the first 3 months after its launched and has a very high star rating on Amazon.com. It's been the product focus for new nutritional consultants at PetSmart and PetCo and has received good in-store activation feedback. Building on our success in the U.S., it has just been launched in Europe. 
And as we look into 2016, there's more exciting innovation news, which we will discuss with you on future calls. 
So in summary, we're pleased with the continued solid organic sales growth and market share gains around the world. Our innovation pipeline is as full as ever and our savings programs are on track. 
Colgate people around the world continue to focus on our 4 strategic initiatives, delivering consistent results. So we look forward to sharing our results with you as we finish the year.
And now, Kelly, I should like to turn it over for questions.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Dara Mohsenian with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Dara Mohsenian with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first, Ian, just a detailed question. I think last quarter, you indicated local currency advertising will be roughly flat year-over-year as a percent of sales in 2015. Is that still the case? Are you thinking about that line item? And then the real que
componenttext: So first, Ian, just a detailed question. I think last quarter, you indicated local currency advertising will be roughly flat year-over-year as a percent of sales in 2015. Is that still the case? Are you thinking about that line item? And then the real question on that front is, it's now been 6 quarters in a row were AMP has been down substantially as a percentage of sales. I know you've indicated before it's been funneled back into the promotion recess been the effective give it a market share performance. But the level of pullback in AMT is really striking relative to your traditionally where you've run the business. So I guess what gives you confidence this won't come back to bite you in the long run in terms of lower demand going forward, particularly given the macro situation out there right now?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Thanks. Thanks. And as you can imagine, not an unexpected question. And in answering it, as you did, let's take a little bit broader perspective and then come back to your specific question. So the world we're dealing in today in terms of our categor
componenttext: Yes, Thanks. Thanks. And as you can imagine, not an unexpected question. And in answering it, as you did, let's take a little bit broader perspective and then come back to your specific question. So the world we're dealing in today in terms of our categories, so I'm talking Colgate businesses now and the categories in which we do business, North America economic scene, we have a world where our categories are growing between 0% and 2% in the developed world, in Europe, the low end of that and in the U.S. at the upper end of that 0% to 2% growth. In the emerging markets, through this call, the growth rates in our categories continue to be mid-single digits generally. And our objective, business objective in that arena has been to have a sustainable rates of growth organically in that 4% to 7% range that we mentioned at the beginning of the year, which we think we continue into the third quarter. And we continue to talk about 4% to 7% for the year. And indeed, as we think about 2016, we begin our budgeting process with the same ambition next year and the way that you get that consistent rate of growth is by building your brands. And you build your brands as measured in market share. And as we choose investment vehicles to build those brands, you're focusing on trial and repeat purchase of our new innovation and our existing businesses. And don't forget in many of these emerging markets, consumer behavior is challenged by local category conditions in those markets and in-store engagement can be more persuasive than what we're educated as being proper advertising investment. So we balance and like to think we invest smartly in traditional media, the traditional television, magazine, radio, sampling devices that would be in that, that advertising number, with an increasing shift as being pointed  out to digital, digital being most lower cost than the battery of return and frankly, Latin America with millennials are now the predominant parent generation, a better way of engaging with that Colgate group. And then as you indicated, the in-store work that we do that in this volatile times can be particularly powerful. Now all of that said, as we think about going forward, we begin our process for the budget in 2016 even though we haven't yet fully began that process if we look at the array of innovation we have over the next 3 years, starting in 2016. I think it would be safe to say that our expectation that our traditional advertising ratios would be up in 2016.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is that on a local currency basis or is that overall company? And also, can give us a sense of where you kind of lead 2015 in terms of the ad ratio?

componenttextpreview: Well, the ad ratio will be according to our current plans for 2015, will be up quarter-on-quarter for the balance of the year and now on I'm talking income statement, so I'm talking dollar. And if you think about 2016, I think at this stage, the expectati
componenttext: Well, the ad ratio will be according to our current plans for 2015, will be up quarter-on-quarter for the balance of the year and now on I'm talking income statement, so I'm talking dollar. And if you think about 2016, I think at this stage, the expectation would be dollar and of course, therefore local currency given what they think most believe will be an improving or at least a less bad foreign exchange environment.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, Bina, you talked about the Brazilian competitive environment as still being fairly intense. But can you talk a little bit more qualitatively. Is that price based competition? Is they're more advertising? Is they're more innovation just fight
componenttext: First of all, Bina, you talked about the Brazilian competitive environment as still being fairly intense. But can you talk a little bit more qualitatively. Is that price based competition? Is they're more advertising? Is they're more innovation just fighting for cellphone space just I know you're sure is are good but directionally, what are you seeing there? And then just separately, housekeeping on Hill's. Can you remind us what the split is U.S. versus international sales now for Hill's and maybe in the quarter, how sales performance differed by region?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brazil, I don't actually recall Bina's language but frankly, the Brazilian environment hasn't become particularly more competitive than historically. It continues to be a competitive marketplace to be sure but again, back to my answer to Dara, we --
componenttext: Yes, Brazil, I don't actually recall Bina's language but frankly, the Brazilian environment hasn't become particularly more competitive than historically. It continues to be a competitive marketplace to be sure but again, back to my answer to Dara, we -- with the programs we have and with the innovation we have, we see our market share is continuing to grow and at 72, as Bina said, it's the highest in the last 20 years with our principal competitors both down. So frankly, at this stage, whatever the threats are in the marketplace, we seem to be meeting them. If we turn to your second question, which was around Hill's, I think it would be fair to say broader terms that Hill's is about 50-50 U.S., domestic, international business split.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Any trends internationally versus U.S. in terms of growth for Hill's similar?
componenttext: Any trends internationally versus U.S. in terms of growth for Hill's similar?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Similar, yes. I mean, the innovation moves from the U.S. around the world and I'm proud to say things like metabolic and metabolic plus are having similar impact wherever we take them. So, yes.
componenttext: Similar, yes. I mean, the innovation moves from the U.S. around the world and I'm proud to say things like metabolic and metabolic plus are having similar impact wherever we take them. So, yes.

componenttextpreview: No, you didn't, Caroline. And I'm sure many of you have not yet had the chance to get to our [indiscernible], which was posted earlier this morning. But as you well know from the financial literature and the decisions that 1 makes in this space, any decis
componenttext: No, you didn't, Caroline. And I'm sure many of you have not yet had the chance to get to our [indiscernible], which was posted earlier this morning. But as you well know from the financial literature and the decisions that 1 makes in this space, any decision that we would take to deconsolidate would be driven by our inability on an ongoing basis to get dollars or if we face additional restrictions on our ability to make local operating decisions on the ground. Clearly, these are things that we revisit quarter upon quarter. And we duly did so for this quarter, Caroline. But the some thoughts on circumstances and the assessment we made, we have chosen to keep reporting Venezuela this quarter and of course, that is a subject that we will revisit period by period as time goes on.

componenttextpreview: Well, remember, the government approved pricing that we got in Venezuela, which I think is about 70-plus percent, 74%, if I remember correctly. That was in the fourth quarter of last year. So obviously, you have the rollover effect. There is some pricing
componenttext: Well, remember, the government approved pricing that we got in Venezuela, which I think is about 70-plus percent, 74%, if I remember correctly. That was in the fourth quarter of last year. So obviously, you have the rollover effect. There is some pricing obviously, we got for the nonregulated businesses. But I would tell you that we are getting pricing across Latin America from Mexico down to Argentina.

Perhaps, online although identity ROI there is still pretty fee because of the long-term history. So how do you balance that? headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very good and deep question, Ali, as usual. The answer is not either or. And they think that if you were to go back to again the days when many marketing bones, in-store activity was pretty rudimentary. There was a cardboard displays stuck at the end of t
componenttext: Very good and deep question, Ali, as usual. The answer is not either or. And they think that if you were to go back to again the days when many marketing bones, in-store activity was pretty rudimentary. There was a cardboard displays stuck at the end of the self with $0.99 off flag on it, hardly brand building in nature and that is why everybody has this average, if you will, to in-store investment versus the supposed quality of the engagement we get from their traditional media, understanding that, that will today is so fragmented that it is less precise than perhaps many of us believed historically. So no, obviously, you don't find yourself in a place where all of your engagement with consumer happens at the retail level. But with the data available to us today, with the techniques available to us today, with some of the in-store engagement materials available to us to today, which are brand and benefit and therapy Colgate, specific, including sometimes the coloring of the shelves, the house, Oral Care part of that retail, that is wonderful environment to get consumers to make that final decision, particularly if they are in a stressed, highly devalued geography. You still have the advertising and we can debate traditional versus the style that is making the awareness connection and seeking to provoke the trial but you miss everything if you don't get a gauge with that consumer when they come to that store to make sure that trial is your product. So yes, it is not a balance. So it is not a journey to everything at retail. But I think the historical perceptions of what you can do at retail and frankly, a prejudice that tasted like YouTube what read their respective phase and not the brand building. I'm afraid it's a little bit old-school..

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's clearly a very good question, Bill. And obviously, where I to right, I have to kill you. I think the headline would be I think the are very thoughtful and we are very strategic about acquisition. You have seen that I think in of those th
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's clearly a very good question, Bill. And obviously, where I to right, I have to kill you. I think the headline would be I think the are very thoughtful and we are very strategic about acquisition. You have seen that I think in of those things that we have acquired. We are always specifically open to the right across the right time. As you know these things are a little bit of process of serendipity, however, much you [indiscernible] and then we are always very disciplined on valuation. You have to leave with what you buy for that best amount of the company for the long haul. So I think my answer will be we're as interested in acquisitions as we were in Sanex and GABA and Thompson the laser brand in Myanmar. And if more were to become available and if the price was right, you would see us going forward as we have been over our recent past. But I wouldn't make it a tilting point now versus previously.

componenttext: Well, it's actually difficult to do, Jason, because measured against net. So what I can tell you is that what you are calling trade spending is up this year. But to come back to your more fundamental question, a few things. #1, this notion of shopper marketing is not a third quarter 2015 comment. We have been trying to make this point unsuccessfully for the last 2 to 3 years for the reasons I detailed a little bit earlier. We believe well done, it is part of building brands. #2, you're right, digital I think will become an important way to target and reach different consumer groups going forward and that carries with it a different dollar to the traditional media. But no, I would not take the notion that forever going forward, our traditional media to sales percentage, the 1 you do see will be lower and stay lower. That, as I said earlier in response to a question, I think will be driven by the innovation spread that we have. And as I said earlier, even though we haven't finished the budget process, actually, we haven't even started the budget process. But if you look at innovation grid for the next 3 years, starting in 2016, I think my expectation would be that you will see that ratio head back up a little bit in 2016. So it will move around. I'm just trying to assert that there's no good and bad, it's all in the marketing mix and they are all legitimate ways of engaging with consumers and particularly in volatile times with high devaluations, that closure, if you will, with the consumer on sale in those highly devolved emerging markets happens in that retail environment.

componenttext: Yes, so let's take a step back, Olivia. Clearly, when we began this program, which by the way is a lot shorter than the many of our competitors. But when we began the program, we had 3 key areas, and we said at the beginning that it was a Global Growth and Efficiency Program and that it was a journey. So we're establishing hubs and we were establishing this service centers. And we were transferring, lifting and shifting, if you will, capabilities to the new structure that we will building that was supported by SAP across our company. So this gives us the opportunity to transform a little bit what we are doing with the new structure that we are creating and do it in a time-bound window of 2017 rather than extending it over a longer period. So it is very definitely within the 3 areas that we define at the beginning of the restructuring. No new areas us. It is definitely 1 more year. And as we said in the release, we'll be coming back to you early in the new year with flesh out ranges of costs for the program and savings. So on that one, we'll be back to you in the New Year.

componenttext: So just a couple of quick ones. In the shadow, have you seen much in a way of deflationary impact due to lower commodity cost, which seemed to be impacting the mass channel? Has that slowed into that time for you? And then secondly, just curious about the cash you've been building, the cash and sources. Are you able to repatriate like you've been able to do on in the past the cash generation, especially in emerging markets back to the U.S.? Or is most of that locked into those markets?

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015

componenttext: On the first, again, without being, the answer is a simple no, particularly in our segments of the Pet Nutrition business business, which tends to be the more premium. And so we have not seen it creep to speciality. Cash repatriation, Venezuela is a Venezuela. Absent Venezuela, the same as it has always been. So we have the ability to repatriate. Sometimes timing is variable country by country, but no change from prior.

They happen to do an awful lot on Facebook and they happen to be avid viewers of YouTube videos. So you want to connect with that group and the best way to get your advertising message to that group is YouTube videos and to do so in a way that it is purpose driven. So if you were to Google all of that, you'd see some pretty interesting work from our point of view but it tends to be more driven by the viewer than it does by the category. Okay. Well, good. Sorry, is that it?
